SPAN 1.title: Elementary Spanish I
SPAN 1.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-  enrolling in the proper course.
SPAN 1.description: Students will learn to use Spanish for communication in real, meaningful situations. This course will develop an understanding of basic grammatical concepts along with obtaining an appreciation of the various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. The course follows a communicative approach and class time is primarily used for communication practice and Spanish will be spoken in class 99% of the time. By the end of this course students are expected to develop proficiency at the Novice-mid level.

SPAN W 1.title: Online Elementary Spanish I
SPAN W 1.comments:
No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
Repeat Comments: Same course as Spanish 1 and Spanish 1SS.
SPAN W 1.description: Span W1 is the first course of the Elementary Spanish three course sequence delivered in a fully online format. By the end of this course students are expected to develop basic proficiency in Spanish at the Novice-mid level.

SPAN 2.title: Elementary Spanish II
SPAN 2.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-  enrolling in the proper course.
SPAN 2.description: Students will learn to use Spanish for communication in real, meaningful situations. This course will develop an understanding of basic grammatical concepts along with  obtaining an appreciation of the various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. The course follows a communicative approach and class time is primarily used for communication practice and Spanish will be spoken in class 99% of the time. By the end of this course students are expected to develop proficiency at the Novice-high level.
SPAN 2.recommended_prep: Same course as Span W2 and Span 2SS. Not open for additional units of credit to students who have completed Span W 2 or Span 2SS.

SPAN 2HY.title: Accelerated Elementary Spanish I
SPAN 2HY.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter. No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Spanish 2 or Spanish 2SS.
SPAN 2HY.description: Face-to-face classroom contact combined with online work. SPAN 2HY and 3HY form a two-course series equivalent to the SPAN 1, 2, 3 Elementary Spanish series. Intended for students with at least 2 years of high school Spanish.
SPAN 2HY.recommended_prep: At least two years of high school Spanish or equivalent preparation.

SPAN W 2.title: Online Elementary Spanish II
SPAN W 2.comments: Online version of Span 2 and Span 2SS.  Not open for additional units of credit to students who have completed Span 2 and Span 2SS.
SPAN W 2.description: SPAN W 2 is the second of the three Elementary Spanish courses offered in a fully online format. Its online format combines technology-based language instruction with online class meetings and live guided conversation sessions. Course materials and activities focus on consolidating the same array of skills promoted in the regular Elementary Span II course. Students learn to use Spanish for communication in real, meaningful situations, develop an understanding of basic grammatical concepts and an appreciation of the various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. Each week, students attend one online class session and one conversation session. There is individual work with the textbook, online materials, and other web-based activities.
SPAN W 2.recommended_prep: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.

SPAN 3.title: Elementary Spanish III
SPAN 3.prereq_description: Spanish 2 with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher.
SPAN 3.comments:
No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have taken SPAN 3HY.
SPAN 3.description: Students will learn to use Spanish for communication in real, meaningful situations. This course will develop an understanding of basic grammatical concepts along with obtaining an appreciation of various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. The course follows a communicative approach and class time is primarily used for communication practice; Spanish will be spoken in class 99% of the time. By the end of this course students are expected to develop proficiency at the Novice-high or Intermediate-low level.

SPAN 3HY.title: Accelerated Elementary Spanish II
SPAN 3HY.prereq_description: Completion of Spanish 2 or Spanish 2HY with a grade of P, or a grade of C
SPAN 3HY.comments:
No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Spanish 3, Spanish 3SS, or higher level courses.
SPAN 3HY.description: Continuation of Span 2HY in areas of grammar and basic language skills. Face-to-face classroom contact combined with online work. SPAN 2HY and 3HY form a two-course series equivalent to the SPAN 1, 2, 3 Elementary Spanish series.

SPAN W 3.title: Online Elementary Spanish III
SPAN W 3.prereq_description: Spanish 2 with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher.
SPAN W 3.comments:
Online version of Span 3. Not open for additional units of credit to students who have completed Span 3 or Span 3HY. No credit can be earned if more advanced work has been completed.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have taken SPAN 3HY or SPAN 3.
SPAN W 3.description: SPAN W3 is the third of the three Elementary Spanish courses offered in a fully online format. Its online format combines technology-based language instruction with online class meetings and live guided conversation sessions. The course materials and activities focus on consolidating the same array of skills promoted in the regular Elementary Spanish III course. Students will learn to use Spanish for communication in real, meaningful situations, develop an understanding of basic grammatical concepts and an appreciation of the various cultures of the Spanish-speaking world. By the end of this course students are expected to develop proficiency at the Novice-high or Intermediate-low level.

SPAN 4.title: Intermediate Spanish I
SPAN 4.prereq_description: Spanish 3, Spanish 3SS, 3HY, with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher; or
SPAN 4.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
SPAN 4.description: Begins review of basic grammar and syntax.

SPAN 5.title: Intermediate Spanish II
SPAN 5.prereq_description: Spanish 4 with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher; or a score of 4 on
SPAN 5.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
SPAN 5.description: Continues the review of basic grammar and syntax. Course conducted in Spanish.

SPAN 6.title: Intermediate Spanish III
SPAN 6.prereq_description: Spanish 5 with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher; or a score of 5 on the AP Spanish Language Examination; or a score of 5 on the AP Spanish Language and Culture Examination; or a score of 3 on the AP Spanish Literature Examination; or a score of 4 on the AP Spanish Literature and Culture Examination.
SPAN 6.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has already been awarded. Students enrolled in an inappropriate level will be assisted in re-enrolling in the proper course.
SPAN 6.description: An intensive course designed to develop students' skills in reading, oral, and written expression by reading and discussing Hispanic texts, and writing compositions on related topics.

SPAN 8A.title: Spanish Conversation
SPAN 8A.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit than Spanish 4 has already been awarded.
SPAN 8A.description: Conversational practice through which the student learns idioms, conversational courtesies of the language, etc., and improves facility in speaking and understanding the spoken language.

SPAN 8B.title: Spanish Conversation
SPAN 8B.prereq_description: Spanish 4, or A.P. score >= 4, or Spanish placement exam = 4, or Spanish 8A.
SPAN 8B.description: Conversational practice through which the student learns idioms, conversational courtesies of the language, etc., and improves facility in speaking and understanding the spoken language.

SPAN 16A.title: SPANISH FOR HERITAGE SPEAKERS
SPAN 16A.comments: NO CREDIT CAN BE EARNED IF MORE ADVANCED CREDIT IN THE LANGUAGE HAS ALREADYBEEN AWARDED. STUDENTS ENROLLED IN AN INAPPROPRIATE LEVEL WILL BE ASSISTED IN RE-ENROLLING IN THE PROPER COURSE.
SPAN 16A.description: ADDRESSES ON A UNIVERSITY LEVEL THE NEEDS AND STRENGTHS OF STUDENTS WITH SPANISH SPEAKING BACKGROUND BUT NO FORMAL LANGUAGE TRAINING IN SPANISH SPEAKING COUNTRIES. EMPHASIZES SKILL IN COMPOSITION, ADVANCED READING COMPREHENSION, STANDARD VERSUS VERNACULAR USAGES, CROSS LANGUAGE INTERFERENCE, ETC.

SPAN 16B.title: SPANISH FOR HERITAGE SPEAKERS
SPAN 16B.comments: NO CREDIT CAN BE EARNED IF MORE ADVANCED CREDIT IN THE LANGUAGE HAS ALREADYBEEN AWARDED. STUDENTS ENROLLED IN AN INAPPROPRIATE LEVEL WILL BE ASSISTED IN RE-ENROLLING IN THE PROPER COURSE.
SPAN 16B.description: ADDRESSES ON UNIVERSITY LEVEL THE NEEDS AND STRENGTHS OF STUDENTS WITH SPANISH SPEAKING BACKGROUND BUT NO FORMAL LANGUAGE TRAINING IN SPANISH SPEAKING COUNTRIES. EMPHASIZES MORE COMPLEX SKILLS IN COMPOSITION AND ADVANCED READING COMPREHENSION THAN SPANISH 16A, AS WELL AS STANDARD VERSUS VERNACULAR USAGES, CROSS LANGUAGE INTERFERENCES, ETC.

SPAN 25.title: Advanced Grammar and Composition
SPAN 25.prereq_description: Spanish 6 with a grade of P or a grade of C or higher; or a score of 4 or 5 on the AP Spanish Literature Examination; or a score of 5 on the AP Spanish Literature and Culture Examination.
SPAN 25.comments: No credit can be earned if more advanced credit in the language has  already been awarded. Designed for non-native speakers; not open to students who have scored a 1 on the Spanish Fluency Evaluation.
SPAN 25.description: Intensive course taught in Spanish designed to reinforce students' comprehension and ability to express themselves in Spanish, both orally and in writing, and to develop the students' vocabularies and awareness of syntactical structures in the language.

SPAN 30.title: Introduction to Hispanic Literature
SPAN 30.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Spanish 102L.
SPAN 30.description: Hispanic Literature in relation to literary problems in general. Such topics as:the functions of literature, literary periods, movements and trends. The analysis and interpretation of texts.

SPAN 31.title: Literatures of the Spanish Speaking World
SPAN 31.description: Explores representative texts from one or more literary periods such as  the Middle Ages, the Golden Age, Colonial Latin American Literature,   Modern and Contemporary Latin American Literature, and/or US Latino  Literature. Texts and topics to be selected by instructors.

SPAN 100.title: Introduction to Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN 100.prereq_description: SPAN 16B or SPAN 25 (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 100.comments: Prerequisite to all other upper-division courses in Hispanic linguistics.
SPAN 100.description: Introduction to linguistic theories, methods, and problems as applied to Spanish. Taught in Spanish with Spanish examples.

SPAN 101.title: American Spanish
SPAN 101.description: Geographical, social, and stylistic distribution of phonemic,      morphosyntactic, and lexical features in Spanish as spoken in Latin    America.

SPAN 102A.title: Advanced Composition through Literature
SPAN 102A.prereq_description: Spanish 6 or Spanish 25 or Spanish 16A or Spanish 16B.
SPAN 102A.comments: Required for teaching credential candidates with a major in Spanish.
SPAN 102A.description: The study of the finer points of Spanish grammar and syntax. Stress is placed on writing critical analyses of literary readings.

SPAN 102B.title: Advanced Composition through Literature
SPAN 102B.prereq_description: Spanish 6 or Spanish 25 or Spanish 16A or Spanish 16B.
SPAN 102B.comments: Required for teaching credential candidates with major in Spanish.
SPAN 102B.description: The study of the finer points of Spanish grammar and syntax. Stress is placed on writing critical analyses of literary readings.

SPAN 103.title: Beyond Advanced Spanish Proficiency
SPAN 103.description: Designed to provide students who have completed Span 25 or Span 16B and one additional upper-division Spanish course with the opportunity to practice the four language skills: speaking, listening, reading, and writing. Students will practice different communicative skills, from defending an opinion to mastering transactions and exchanges.

SPAN 104.title: Teaching Spanish for Heritage Speakers
SPAN 104.description: Designed for students who have completed Span 100 and who are considering a teaching career. The course covers frequent issues encountered when working with students who have learned Spanish through their family history or place of origin.

SPAN 105.title: Spanish/English Contrasts
SPAN 105.description: The scope of this course is the Spanish language and its differences vis-a-vis English, ranging from pronunciation and grammar to word meaning, language use, and social and dialectical variation.

SPAN 106.title: Introduction to Latin American and Iberian Studies
SPAN 106.description: Designed to acquaint students with current research on the main areas of Latin American and Iberian Studies. Taught in English.

SPAN 107.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to the History and Societies of Latin America and Iberia
SPAN 107.description: Issues central to the study of Latin America and Iberia across the social sciences and history. Topics include nationalism, revolution, politics and the state, economic development and international relations, labor, popular culture, race, gender, religion, migration, environment, imperialism, and colonialism. Taught in English.

SPAN 108.title: Interdisciplinary Approaches to the Cultures, Languages, and Literatures of Latin America and Iberia
SPAN 108.description: Issues pertinent to the diverse cultures, languages, and literatures of Latin America and Iberia. Disciplines and approaches may include: pre-Columbian studies, Spanish and Spanish American literatures, Portuguese and Brazilian literatures, translation studies, cultural, gender, and queer studies, romance language and linguistics. Taught in English.

SPAN 109.title: Spanish in the United States: The Language and Its Speakers
SPAN 109.description: Study of Spanish used in United States by native and immigrant groups:   Mexicans, Chicanos, Cubans, Puerto Ricans and others in Spanish-speaking enclaves. Focus on language and social and cultural manifestations arising in contact between linguistically different groups. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 110A.title: Spanish Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 110A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L or Spanish 30 (may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 110B.title: Spanish Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 110B.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Spanish 30 (may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 110C.title: Spanish Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 110C.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Spanish 30 (may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 110D.title: Spanish Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 110D.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 111A.title: Spanish-American Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 111A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 111B.title: Spanish-American Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 111B.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 111C.title: Spanish-American Literature from the Beginning to the Present
SPAN 111C.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).

SPAN 112A.title: Non-Castilian Literatures of Spain
SPAN 112A.description: Introduction to Spains medieval linguistic and cultural diversity through literary works written in such languages as Latin, Arabic, Hebrew,   Mozarabic, Occitan, Catalan-Valencian, Galician-Portuguese and Galician. Texts read in Spanish or English translation.

SPAN 112B.title: Non-Castilian Literatures of Spain
SPAN 112B.description: Introduction to Spain?s linguistic and cultural diversity in modern and contemporary times through literary works written in Asturian, Basque, Catalan and Galician. Texts read in Spanish translation.

SPAN 114A.title: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach
SPAN 114A.description: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make     communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the  Spanish system, as follows: phonetics and phonemics.

SPAN 114B.title: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach
SPAN 114B.description: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make     communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the  Spanish system, as follows: morphology and syntax.

SPAN 114C.title: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach
SPAN 114C.description: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make     communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the  Spanish system, as follows: semantics.

SPAN 115.title: Introduction to Translation I
SPAN 115.description: Comprises topics necessary to develop skills that are needed for writing at a specialized level and to carry out written translation into and from Spanish, mostly texts on business and medical topics.

SPAN 116.title: Introduction to Interpreting
SPAN 116.prereq_description: SPAN 16B or SPAN 25 (may be taken concurrently)
SPAN 116.description: Comprised of topics necessary in developing skills for interpretation to and from Spanish. Intended mostly for proficient Spanish-language speakers.

SPAN 117A.title: Specialized Translation - Medical
SPAN 117A.description: Comprised of topics necessary in developing skills for writing at a specialized level, and with specialized vocabulary, for the medical profession.

SPAN 117B.title: Specialized Translation - Legal
SPAN 117B.description: Comprised of topics necessary in developing skills for writing at a specialized level, and with specialized vocabulary, for the legal profession.

SPAN 117C.title: Specialized Translation - Technical
SPAN 117C.comments:
Same course as Comparative Literature 102C.
Repeat Comments: SPAN 117C is a legal repeat of C LIT 102C.
SPAN 117C.description: Comprised of topics necessary in developing skills for writing at a specialized level, and with specialized vocabulary and format, for the translation of different types of technical texts (instruction manuals, medical, patents, etc.).

SPAN 117D.title: Specialized Translation - Film Subtitling
SPAN 117D.description: Comprised of topics necessary in developing skills for translating subtitles.

SPAN 118A.title: Advanced Interpreting - Community Interpreting
SPAN 118A.description: Comprised of topics fundamental in developing skills for interpretation to and from Spanish for the Hispanic community.

SPAN 118B.title: Advanced Interpreting - Medical Interpreting
SPAN 118B.description: Comprised of topics fundamental in developing skills for interpretation to and from Spanish for the medical profession.

SPAN 118C.title: Advanced Interpreting - Legal & Court Interpreting
SPAN 118C.description: Comprised of topics fundamental in developing skills for interpretation to and from Spanish in a legal setting and for the courts.

SPAN 119A.title: Spanish Institutions and Culture
SPAN 119A.prereq_description: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 119A.description: Study of the development of the Spanish nation, with special focus on key  social and political institutions, the arts and major currents of thought.

SPAN 120A.title: Contemporary Spanish-American Fiction (in English Translation)
SPAN 120A.description: Reading and discussion of novels and short stories by Borges, Carpentier, Cortazar, Garcia Marquez, Vargas Llosa, and others.

SPAN 120B.title: Contemporary Spanish-American Fiction (in English Translation)
SPAN 120B.description: Reading and discussion of representative works of contemporary Mexican author, including Yanez, Rulfo, Fuentes, and others.

SPAN 121.title: Language and History in the Hispanic World
SPAN 121.description: The different languages spoken in the Hispanic world: their origins,   development, convergence, divergence, and diffusion in relation to   historical processes.

SPAN 122A.title: Medieval Spanish Literature
SPAN 122A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 122A.description: A detailed survey of the main trends in Spanish literature to 1500.

SPAN 122B.title: Medieval Spanish Literature
SPAN 122B.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 122B.description: A detailed survey of the main trends in Spanish literature to 1500.

SPAN 123A.title: Hispanic Balladry
SPAN 123A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 123A.description: History of the Spanish ballad; Hispanic balladry in Spanish America, the United States, and among the Shepardic Jews.

SPAN 124.title: Psycholinguistics
SPAN 124.comments:
Spanish 124 is the Spanish version of Spanish 124E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 124 is a legal repeat of Spanish 124E.
SPAN 124.description: An introduction to core areas of Spanish psycholinguistics: speech perception, word recognition, language comprehension, language production, first language acquisition, bilingualism, language disorders and aphasiology. Goals: 1)to introduce students to the key findings and central debates within psycholinguistic research; 2)to introduce students to the tools and methods of psycholinguistic research; 3)to introduce students to research practice; 4)to manage effective interaction within the intercultural context. Students will develop an experiment design, and collect/analyze data. Depending on their performance, students will be invited to work and/or volunteer at the Bilingualism, Translation, & Cognition Laboratory.

SPAN 124E.title: Psycholinguistics
SPAN 124E.comments:
Spanish 124E is the English version of Spanish 124.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 124E is a legal repeat of Spanish 124.
SPAN 124E.description: An introduction to core areas of Spanish psycholinguistics: speech perception, word recognition, language comprehension, language production, first language acquisition, bilingualism, language disorders & aphasiology. Goals: 1)to introduce students to the key findings & central debates within psycholinguistic research; 2)to introduce students to the tools and methods of psycholinguistic research; 3)to introduce students to research practice; 4)to manage effective interaction within the intercultural context. Students will develop an experiment design, and collect/analyze data. Depending on their performance, students will be invited to work and/or volunteer at the Bilingualism, Translation, & Cognition Laboratory. Taught in English.

SPAN 125.title: Introduction to Romance Linguistics
SPAN 125.description: Illustrates principles of comparative-historical linguistic analysis by  examining Romance languages (French, Portuguese, etc.) for similarities  and differences, and tracing their evolution from Vulgar Latin.

SPAN 126.title: Spanish Cinema
SPAN 126.description: Covers different periods of the Spanish cinema history and the way movies could represent the history and culture of the twentieth century in Spain.

SPAN 126E.title: Spanish Cinema
SPAN 126E.comments:
Spanish 126E is the English version of Spanish 126.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 126E is a legal repeat of Spanish 126.
SPAN 126E.description: Covers different periods of the Spanish cinema history and the way movies could represent the history and culture of the twentieth century in Spain. Taught in English.

SPAN 128.title: Creative Writing
SPAN 128.prereq_description: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 128.description: Designed primarily for students who are inclined to write fictional prose  and/or poetry in Spanish.

SPAN 129.title: Sociolinguistics of Iberian Languages
SPAN 129.description: Focus is on the social and cultural history of the different languages in the Iberian Peninsula, including Spanish - whether in Spain, Latin  America or the U.S. The course analyzes and compares their present   status within mostly bilingual communities.

SPAN 130.title: The Fantastic and Its Development in Spanish-American Short Story
SPAN 130.prereq_description: A minimum grade of "C" in Spanish 102L, OR a minimum grade of "C" in Spanish 30.
SPAN 130.description: Exploration of the multiple manifestations of the Fantastic in Spanish American short story from its origin, linked to nineteenth-century sensationalistic journalism, up to neofantastic mode appearing circa 1950, with its more epistemological goals.

SPAN 131.title: Spanish Golden Age Poetry I
SPAN 131.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 131.description: Lyric poetry of the sixteenth century: Garcilaso, Luis de Leon, San Juan de La Cruz, and others.

SPAN 132.title: The Spanish Civil War: Conflict, Culture, and Memory
SPAN 132.comments:
Spanish 132 is the Spanish version of Spanish 132E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 132 is a legal repeat of Spanish 132E.
SPAN 132.description: An introduction to the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), an event that had a tremendous impact over Spain's twentieth-century history, culture, and society. Through the study of distinct number of cultural products (memoirs, novels, films, photographs...), we cover the social and cultural history of the war, the way it has been represented in different periods of history, as well as why and how it has been the inspiration of many works of art (Picasso), films (Del Toro) and literary pieces (Max Aub) produced all over the world.

SPAN 132E.title: The Spanish Civil War: Conflict, Culture, and Memory
SPAN 132E.comments:
Spanish 132E is the English version of Spanish 132.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 132E is a legal repeat of Spanish 132.
SPAN 132E.description: An introduction to the Spanish Civil War (1936-1939), an event that had a tremendous impact over Spain's twentieth-century history, culture, and society. Through the study of distinct number of cultural products (memoirs, novels, films, photographs...), we cover the social and cultural history of the war, the way it has been represented in different periods of history, as well as why and how it has been the inspiration of many works of art (Picasso), films (Del Toro) and literary pieces (Max Aub) produced all over the world.  Taught in English.

SPAN 133.title: Spanish Laughter: The Politics of Humor in Spain
SPAN 133.comments:
Spanish 133 is the Spanish version of Spanish 133E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 133 is a legal repeat of Spanish 133E.
SPAN 133.description: This course presents a historical account of humor in Spain, and the evolution of its political value. Through the analysis of a wide range of cultural artifacts such as short stories, tv shows, films, comic books, and paintings, we will analyze the changing role that humor has played in the Spanish public sphere from the early modern period to the present day, as well as how it has been an important tool that Spaniards have taken advantage of to address different social fears and challenges.

SPAN 133E.title: Spanish Laughter: The Politics of Humor in Spain
SPAN 133E.comments:
Spanish 133E is the English version of Spanish 133.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 133E is a legal repeat of Spanish 133.
SPAN 133E.description: This course presents a historical account of humor in Spain, and the evolution of its political value. Through the analysis of a wide range of cultural artifacts such as short stories, tv shows, films, comic books, and paintings, we will analyze the changing role that humor has played in the Spanish public sphere from the early modern period to the present day, as well as how it has been an important tool that Spaniards have taken advantage of to address different social fears and challenges. Taught in English.

SPAN 134.title: Spain at the Crossroads: Tradition and Modernity
SPAN 134.description: Selected topics related to the study of the major literary movements and currents of thought in Spanish Literature during the 18th and 19th centuries, such as Enlightenment, "Costumbrismo", Nationalism, Romanticism, Realism, or Naturalism. Analysis of the major poets, playwrights, and novelists of the period. Readings and discussions in Spanish.

SPAN 135.title: Survey of Chicano Literature
SPAN 135.description: The course encompasses a general overview of all genres (poetry, novel,  theater, short story and essay) of Chicano literature. A people's    socio-historical experiences are examined to understand ethnicity,   creativity, and world view.

SPAN 136.title: Modern Mexican Literature
SPAN 136.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 136.description: Study of texts explaining the development of Mexican culture and literature. Topic and writers: modernism (from Gutierrez Najera to Tablada); the novel of the Mexican revolution (Azuela); and the modern essay (Alfonso Reyes and Octavio Paz).

SPAN 137A.title: Golden Age Drama
SPAN 137A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 137A.description: The classic comedia, by Lope, Tirso, Alarcon, Calderon, and other dramatists.

SPAN 137B.title: Golden Age Drama
SPAN 137B.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 137B.description: The classic comedia, by Lope, Tirso, Alarcon, Calderon, and other dramatists.

SPAN 138.title: Contemporary Mexican Literature
SPAN 138.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 138.description: Continued study of major trends in Mexican literature as evidenced in selected works of the following authors: the poetry of Lopez Velarde and Octavio Paz; the contemporaneos (Torres Bodet, Villaurrutia, Pellicer); and contemporary fiction (Yanez, Rulfo, Arreola, and Fuentes).

SPAN 139.title: U.S. Latino Literature
SPAN 139.comments:
Spanish 139 is the Spanish version of Spanish 139E.
Repeat Comments: SPAN 139 is a legal repeat of SPAN 139E.
SPAN 139.description: A comparative study of the literature and culture of the diverse Latino populations of the United States, including Chicano, Puerto Rican, Cuban-American, Dominican-American, and other U.S. Latino groups. Writers, genres, and periods vary from quarter to quarter, emphasizing salient examples of fiction, poetry, drama, the essay, film or art.

SPAN 140A.title: Cervantes: Don Quijote
SPAN 140A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 140A.description: Reading and discussion of the first and second parts of Don Quixote.

SPAN 140B.title: Cervantes: Don Quijote
SPAN 140B.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 140B.description: Reading and discussion of the first and second parts of Don Quixote.

SPAN 141.title: Contemporary Indigenous Cultures of Mexico
SPAN 141.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently)
SPAN 141.description: Examines the work of writers that have recently provided increased visibility to indigenous languages and cultures in contemporary Mexico, including Nahuatl, Zapotec, and Mayan.

SPAN 142.title: Cognition and Literature in Early Modern Spain
SPAN 142.description: Explore some of the recent theories of cognition and their implication for the problematic links between reality and fiction, truth and falsity, and perception and knowledge in the Early Modern Period.

SPAN 143.title: Culture and Crisis
SPAN 143.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 143.description: Traces the ways in which literature represents crisis in different moments of the Spanish history. The course focuses on fundamental concepts like historical memory, bio politics, insecurity and anti-austerity movements in Contemporary Spain.

SPAN 144.title: Typology of Languages Spoken in the Iberian Peninsula
SPAN 144.description: Comparative study of the structural characteristics of all languages of  the Iberian Peninsula (both the Romance languages - Catalan, Galician,   Portuguese, Spanish - and Basque).  Analysis of similarities and     differences in their phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics.

SPAN 145.title: Spanish for Healthcare
SPAN 145.description: Designed for students interested in expanding and applying their knowledge of Spanish to the medical field. Students will learn and apply targeted vocabulary/grammar and develop bicultural/bilingual competency of healthcare issues in Hispanic countries and the US.

SPAN 146.title: Narratives of Identity: Art, Culture and Politics in Spain
SPAN 146.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 146.description: Focusing on a wide range of its cultural manifestations (Art, Architecture, Cinema, Literature, Language, Gastronomy), this course offers an interdisciplinary approach, conceiving Spain as a multilayered space that is furnished by Roman, French, and Muslim legacies and that drove the shaping of a singular culture.

SPAN 147.title: Business Spanish
SPAN 147.prereq_description: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 or equivalent language proficiency.
SPAN 147.description: Real-life situations in the workplace will present students with the   appropriate vocabulary for business environments.  Students learn to write formal documents, how to express themselves orally, and to assess the  business environment of different Spanish-speaking countries from a    cultural perspective.

SPAN 148AAZZ.title: Filmmakers Series
SPAN 148AAZZ.comments:
May be repeated to a maximum of 12 units provided the letter designation is different.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated to a maximum of 12 units provided the letter designation is different.

SPAN 149.title: Soccer: The Cultural Impact of a Global Game
SPAN 149.comments:
Spanish 149 is the Spanish version of Spanish 149E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 149 is a legal repeat of Spanish 149E.
SPAN 149.description: Soccer is a mirror of our world and an expression of our greatest tragedies and hopes. This course seeks to use soccer as a tool for learning about politics, economics, culture, society, philosophy, art, literature and the human condition in the Hispanic world.

SPAN 149E.title: Soccer: The Cultural Impact of a Global Game
SPAN 149E.comments:
Spanish 149E is the English version of Spanish 149.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 149E is a legal repeat of Spanish 149.
SPAN 149E.description: Soccer is a mirror of our world and an expression of our greatest tragedies and hopes. This course seeks to use soccer as a tool for learning about politics, economics, culture, society, philosophy, art, literature and the human condition in the Hispanic world. Taught in English.

SPAN 150.title: Madrid: from Capital City to Global City
SPAN 150.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L or Spanish 100 (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 150.description: Focuses on the history of the city from the early 19th century to the present, evaluating its serving as the location of political authority, and its material and symbolic function as a command center for the nation. Particular attention is given to Madrid?s city landscape, its streets, avenues, squares and monuments and the historical and emotional impact they carry.

SPAN 151A.title: Catalan Language and Culture
SPAN 151A.comments: Not open for credit for students who have completed Spanish 151.
SPAN 151A.description: Catalan language and culture for students with no previous study of Catalan.

SPAN 151B.title: Catalan Language and Culture
SPAN 151B.description: Catalan language and culture for students with no previous study of Catalan. Continues activities commenced in Spanish 151A.

SPAN 151C.title: Catalan Language and Culture
SPAN 151C.description: Catalan language and culture for students with no previous study of Catalan. Continues activities commenced in Spanish 151A and 151B.

SPAN 152.title: Barcelona and the Catalan Culture
SPAN 152.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (prerequisites may be taken concurrently)
SPAN 152.description: Traces the ways in which cultural legacies are present in the contemporary city providing a difficult yet evenly present balance between tradition and modernity, between convention and originality, between the past, the present, and the future. Through readings of remarkable historians, art critics, urban designers, novelists and poets, and supported by visual materials, the course offers an integrated perspective of the city which opens questions in every field of the humanities and the social sciences about Catalan Culture.

SPAN 153.title: Basque Studies
SPAN 153.comments:
Spanish 153 is the Spanish version of Spanish 153E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 153 is a legal repeat of Spanish 153E.
SPAN 153.description: An overview of the cultural and historical characteristics of the Basque Country while analyzing how minoritized groups, such as the Basque, negotiate their identity in the face of globalization.

SPAN 153E.title: Basque Studies
SPAN 153E.comments:
Spanish 153E is the English version of Spanish 153.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 153E is a legal repeat of Spanish 153.
SPAN 153E.description: An overview of the cultural and historical characteristics of the Basque Country while analyzing how minoritized groups, such as the Basque, negotiate their identity in the face of globalization. Taught in English.

SPAN 154A.title: Basque Language and Culture
SPAN 154A.description: An intensive course for students with no previous study of the Basque language.

SPAN 154C.title: Basque Language and Culture
SPAN 154C.description: Continues activities commenced in SPAN 154A and SPAN 154B.

SPAN 155A.title: Discourses of Love and Desire: from The Book of Good Love to the Present
SPAN 155A.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 155A.description: This course sequence (SPAN 155 A - B) traces the literary constructions, elaborations, and treatments of love in Spanish literature from Middle Ages to the present. SPAN 155A (Pre-1700)  focuses specifically on the development of courtly love and neoplatonic visions of love in the Iberian Peninsula as they pertain to a variety of literary and cultural forms.

SPAN 155B.title: Discourses of Love and Desire: from The Book of Good Love to the Present
SPAN 155B.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 155B.description: This course sequence (SPAN 155 A - B) traces the literary constructions, elaborations, and treatments of love in Spanish literature from Middle Ages to the present. SPAN 155B (Post- 1700) explores the psychological and sociological implications and the cultural significance of love in a variety of art forms, poetry, drama, novel and film.

SPAN 156.title: Introduction to Galician Studies
SPAN 156.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 156.description: The uniqueness of the culture and language of Galicia, its history, ethnography, folklore, and literature, in Galician and Spanish.

SPAN 157.title: Introduction to Digital Humanities
SPAN 157.description: An introduction to the way in which new text formats and tools are changing the way we read, view, communicate, produce knowledge and art and share them in the humanities, specifically in the Hispanic world and/or the U.S. Latinx communities.  The course intertwines literary and creative studies with a focus on the principles of digital media, through the practice of digital desktop publishing using the Adobe Creative Suite. Students are to discuss and reflect critically on a variety of genres and work on a collaborative technical project. Speaking Spanish is not a prerequisite.

SPAN 158.title: Exploring Minor Theatrical Genres: Analysis, Writing, and Staging
SPAN 158.description: Familiarizes students with a usually understudied field, the "minor"   genres of drama during the Golden Age. Combines theory with praxis by  asking the students to write and stage their own "minor" texts as a final  project for the class. Performances are open to the general public.

SPAN 160.title: Literature and Technology in Latin-America
SPAN 160.description: Explores how Latin America theoretical discourses have reflected upon technology, including vaccines, agriculture, film and contemporary cyberpunk fiction.

SPAN 161.title: Horror and Mystery
SPAN 161.description: A panoramic view of short stories and films belonging to the horror genre in Spain and Latin America. The course offers contextualization and analysis of each story or film. Included are short stories by Espronceda, Bécquer, Ochoa, Zorrilla, Quiroga, Cortázar, Anderson Imbert and films by González, Larrañaga, Ibáñez Serrador, Naschy, Franco, Padrón and Brugués.

SPAN 163.title: Nicaraguan Poetry
SPAN 163.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 163.description: Surveys the poetry of Nicaragua from its origins to the present. It frames key authors and representative poetic texts within their literary and cultural context. Poets include Darío, Cortés, Selva, Cuadra, and Belli.

SPAN 164.title: Media Culture
SPAN 164.description: This course studies a variety of cultural practices in the media and related literary texts, including serialized culture such as the telenovela, the radio drama, films, sequels and prequels, comic strips, and social media such as Facebook and Twitter.

SPAN 165.title: Andean Literature, Music, and Culture
SPAN 165.prereq_description: Spanish 30; and Spanish 100 (may be taken concurrently)
SPAN 165.description: This course focuses on literature, music and culture of certain ethnic groups inhabiting the Andean region of South America including, but not limited to, the Aymara and Quechua peoples, their cosmovision and their languages. Through literary texts belonging to different genres, and through films, special attention is placed on expressions of syncretism in seasonal festivals in which pre-Hispanic, European, and African music traditions and religions were shaped due to forced migration, wars and colonization. A strong emphasis on the ecological regions of the nations that share the Andean mountain range contextualizes current indigenous movements of resistance against the degradation of its environment and the impact on its culture.

SPAN 166.title: Borges
SPAN 166.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 166.comments:
Spanish 166 is the Spanish version of Spanish 166E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 166 is a legal repeat of Spanish 166E.
SPAN 166.description: A study of one of the greatest writers of the twentieth century: Jorge Luis Borges. Explores his various creative registers, from his short stories in the vein of fantastic literature, to his poetry and his work as an essayist. The perspective of the course is comparative around topics (some seminal, some relatively unexplored) that Borges treats across a variety of literary genres.

SPAN 166E.title: Borges
SPAN 166E.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 166E.comments:
Spanish 166E is the English version of Spanish 166.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 166E is a legal repeat of Spanish 166.
SPAN 166E.description: A study of one of the greatest writers of the twentieth century: Jorge Luis Borges. Explores his various creative registers, from his short stories in the vein of fantastic literature, to his poetry and his work as an essayist. The perspective of the course is comparative around topics (some seminal, some relatively unexplored) that Borges treats across a variety of literary genres. Taught in English.

SPAN 168.title: Posmodernismo
SPAN 168.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 168.description: Study of the Spanish and Spanish-American Postmodernistas, exploring the link between the culture of modernity and the emergence of a colloquial, prosaic, but lyrical discourse in late nineteenth and twentieth century Spanish and Spanish-  American poetry.

SPAN 169.title: Literature and Cultural Identity in the Spanish Caribbean
SPAN 169.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 169.description: Survey of Spanish Caribbean literature from the standpoint of interaction of culture and race. It traces the counterpoint among the diverse ethnic groups that populate the Caribbean and the manner in which the discourse ofthe oppressor and the oppressed intertwine.

SPAN 170.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 170.description: Readings of such authors as Unamuno, Baroja, Azorin, Valle-Inclan, Antonio Machado, Ortega, Gomez de la Serna, Guillen, Garcia Lorca, and others, analyzed in their historical and social context.

SPAN 172.title: Lorca
SPAN 172.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 172.description: Major poems and plays of Federico Garcia Lorca, including such works as Romancero Gitano, Poeta en Nueva York, Bodas de Sangre, Yerma, La Casa de Bernarda Alba.

SPAN 174.title: The Hispanic Novel and Cinema
SPAN 174.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Spanish 30 (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 174.description: Study of three or four Hispanic novels vis-a-vis their film versions, permitting analysis of narrative in both genres, using existing films and videos based on masterpieces of Hispanic literature. Taught in Spanish.

SPAN 175.title: Contemporary Spanish Literature
SPAN 175.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 175.description: Spanish literature since the Civil War a study of the main trends of post-war Spanish novel, theatre, and poetry, in their historical and socialcontext.

SPAN 177.title: Spanish-American Thought
SPAN 177.prereq_description: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 or equivalent language proficiency.
SPAN 177.description: Leading social, institutional, intellectual, and artistic trends from the  sixteenth century to the present.

SPAN 178.title: Mexican Culture
SPAN 178.prereq_description: Spanish 16A or 16B or 25 or equivalent language proficiency.
SPAN 178.comments: Not open for credit by students who have taken Spanish 180.
SPAN 178.description: Social, institutional, intellectual, and artistic trends in the developmentof modern Mexico.

SPAN 179.title: The Chicano Novel
SPAN 179.description: Reading, analysis and critique of the contemporary Chicano novel as it   pertains to the Chicano experience.

SPAN 180AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Peninsular Literature and Culture
SPAN 180AAZZ.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 180AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 20 units, provided letter designation is different.
SPAN 180AAZZ.description: Special topics in Peninsular literature and culture.

SPAN 181.comments:
Spanish 181 is the Spanish version of Spanish 181E.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 181 is a legal repeat of Spanish 181E.
SPAN 181.description: Reading and discussion of twentieth-century Spanish and Spanish-American poets and trends in their socio-historical context.

SPAN 181E.comments:
Spanish 181E is the English version of Spanish 181.
Repeat Comments: Spanish 181E is a legal repeat of Spanish 181.
SPAN 181E.description: Reading and discussion of twentieth-century Spanish and Spanish-American poets and trends in their socio-historical context. Taught in English.

SPAN 182AAZZ.title: Special Topics in Latin American Literature and Culture
SPAN 182AAZZ.prereq_description: Spanish 30 or Spanish 102L (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 182AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 20 units, provided the letter designation is different.
SPAN 182AAZZ.description: Special topics in Latin American literature and culture.

SPAN 183AAZZ.title: Study of Hispanic Literature by Author or Special Topics
SPAN 183AAZZ.prereq_description: Spanish 102L or Spanish 30 (may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 183AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 20 units, provided letter designation is different. However, only 8 units may be applied towards the Spanish major.
SPAN 183AAZZ.description: Study of Hispanic literature by author or special topics.

SPAN 184.title: Contemporary Spanish-American Short Story
SPAN 184.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 184.description: A study of the trends, themes and techniques of the contemporary Spanish American short story with emphasis on major authors such as Borges, Cortázar, Ocampo, Onetti, Rulfo, Carpentier, García Márquez, and others.

SPAN 185.title: The Spanish-American Nueva Novela
SPAN 185.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 185.description: Readings of such authors as Borges, Rulfo Fuentes, Vargas Llosa, Garcia Marquez, Donoso. Emphasis put on the innovative structure and language brought to Hispanic literature by the so-called Nueva Novela.

SPAN 186AAZZ.title: Selected Topics in Hispanic Linguistics
SPAN 186AAZZ.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 20 units, provided letter   designations are different.
SPAN 186AAZZ.description: Topics for the course reflect the research interests of faculty members.

SPAN 187A.title: Modern Hispanic Drama
SPAN 187A.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 187A.description: Representative dramatists of Spain such as Unamuno, Valle-  Inclan, Garcia Lorca, Buero Vallejo, and others.

SPAN 188.title: Modernismo
SPAN 188.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 188.description: Introduction to the poetry and prose of Hispanic Modernismo. Major writers and their most representative works: Marti, Dario, Rodo, Lugones. Lyric poetry, short story, novel, the essay, and other forms are studied.

SPAN 189.title: Vanguard Poetry in Spanish America
SPAN 189.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Span 30. (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently.)
SPAN 189.description: A survey of the poetry of the Spanish-American avant-guarde focusing on its three main tendencies: colloquial or antipoetic poetry, existentially or politically committed poetry, and self-referential, narcissistic poetry.

SPAN 190.title: Borges and His Precursors
SPAN 190.description: This course focuses on Borges the Reader, and traces in particular his   affinities with North American and European literatures.

SPAN 193A.title: Capstone Seminar - Language and Translation Studies
SPAN 193A.comments: Concurrently offered with Spanish 293A.. Recommended major GPA of 3.5 or higher. Recommended cumulative GPA or 3.0 or higher.   Please see Undergraduate Advisor for approval code.
SPAN 193A.description: The Capstone Seminar offers outstanding Spanish Majors the opportunity to conduct research alongside M.A. and Ph.D. students in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. The course aims to improve the students' critical thinking and ability to analyze and contextualize primary and secondary sources within Language and Translation Studies. Students learn to identify and locate reliable sources, compile and present bibliographical data in a consistent format, and improve their ability to write scholarly prose in clear, idiomatic Spanish.

SPAN 193B.title: Capstone Seminar - Peninsular Spanish Studies
SPAN 193B.comments: Concurrently offered with Spanish 293B.. Recommended major GPA of 3.5 or higher. Recommended cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.  Please see Undergraduate Advisor for approval code.
SPAN 193B.description: The Capstone Seminar offers outstanding Spanish Majors the opportunity to conduct research alongside M.A. and Ph.D. students in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. The course aims to improve the students' critical thinking and ability to analyze and contextualize primary and secondary sources within Peninsular Spanish Literature. Students learn to identify and locate reliable sources, compile and present bibliographical data in a consistent format, and improve their ability to write scholarly prose in clear, idiomatic Spanish.

SPAN 193C.title: Capstone Seminar - Latin American Studies
SPAN 193C.comments: Concurrently offered with Spanish 293C. Recommended major GPA of 3.5 or higher.  Recommended cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.  Please see Undergraduate Advisor for approval code.
SPAN 193C.description: The Capstone Seminar offers outstanding Spanish Majors the opportunity to conduct research alongside M.A. and Ph.D. students in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese. The course aims to improve the students' critical thinking and ability to analyze and contextualize primary and secondary sources within Latin American Literature. Students learn to identify and locate reliable sources, compile and present bibliographical data in a consistent format, and improve their ability to write scholarly prose in clear, idiomatic Spanish.

SPAN 194.title: Spanish American Women's Writing
SPAN 194.prereq_description: Spanish 102L OR Spanish 30 (Prerequisite may be taken concurrently).
SPAN 194.description: An introduction to nineteenth- and twentieth-century Spanish American women's writings. Themes may include women's participation in the formation of national literatures, their engagement with a tradition of women's writing, and issues of authorship and authority.

SPAN 195.title: Senior Honors Independent Research
SPAN 195.description: The student will engage in research lead ing to a paper of considerable depth and complexity on a topic dealing with the literature and/or languageof Spain and Spanish America.

SPAN 196.title: Internship
SPAN 196.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; Spanish or Portuguese majors only; authorization of department.
SPAN 196.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 overall grade-point average. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units.
SPAN 196.description: This course enables students to obtain credit for Spanish or Portuguese related internship experience. The course is graded P/NP and cannot be applied towards credit for the major.

SPAN 197.title: News Translation
SPAN 197.description: Students develop practical and research skills that are of immediate importance to the translation of media texts, using translation examples taken from real-world settings. Upon completion of this course, students should be able to formulate and employ appropriate translation strategies to overcome language and cultural barriers of media texts and translate with confidence non-technical media texts from English to Spanish and vice versa.

SPAN 199.title: Independent Studies in Spanish
SPAN 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of two upper-division courses in Spanisconsent of department.
SPAN 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined.
SPAN 199.description: Independent studies in selected subjects not covered by course offerings.

SPAN 200.title: Studies in Synchronic Linguistics
SPAN 200.description: In-depth study on particular subjects in the field of the phonological,  syntactic, or semantic component, or the lexicon, as applied to modern   Spanish.

SPAN 200SS.title: Linguistic Analysis
SPAN 200SS.description: Study of the phonological and syntactic structure of modern Spanish for  students with a functional command of the language; emphasis placed on   developing ability to analyze grammatical structures and phonetic    principles related to the learning and teaching of Spanish.

SPAN 201SS.title: Writing Strategies and Approaches
SPAN 201SS.description: Development of writing skills through writing original compositions.   Reading and discussion of selected masterpieces to acquaint the student  with a variety of styles. Further grammar review.

SPAN 202.title: Topics in Peninsular Cultural Studies
SPAN 202.description: Every iteration of this course will be organized around a different theme. We will include a wide range of cultural productions from Spain, such as films, popular genres, the press, political discourses, and other non-canonical texts and cultural artifacts related to culture as history. The cultural artifacts will be examined by using critical lenses including identity, race, ideology, power, class, and  historical representation.

SPAN 203SS.title: Spanish Peninsular Texts (1700-present)
SPAN 203SS.description: A close reading of selected modern and contemporary texts in prose and   poetry, that will be set in their historical contexts and carefully    analyzed so as to bring out their meaning(s) or intention(s).

SPAN 204SS.title: Spanish-American Texts (1830-present)
SPAN 204SS.description: A close reading of selected modern and contemporary texts in prose and   poetry, that will be set in their historical contexts and carefully    analyzed so as to bring out their meaning(s) or intentions(s).

SPAN 207SS.title: Cultural History of Spain (pre-1700)
SPAN 207SS.description: A survey of the major events that shaped Spain as a modern state. The  intellectual movements that nurtured and sustained the contemporary Spanishstate will also be studied.

SPAN 208SS.title: Cultural History of Spanish America (pre-1830)
SPAN 208SS.description: A panoramic but in-depth presentation of the major historical and cultural events that give coherence and diversity to the Spanish-speaking countries of the Western Hemisphere.

SPAN 209SS.title: Don Quijote
SPAN 209SS.description: A close reading of both parts of the novel, setting it into its historical context, with appropriate discussion of key episodes.

SPAN 210A.title: Survey of Spanish Literature for Portuguese Graduate Students

SPAN 210B.title: Survey of Spanish literature for Portuguese graduate students

SPAN 210C.title: Survey of Spanish Literature for Portuguese Students

SPAN 210SS.title: Spanish Language in the World: History of the Spanish Language
SPAN 210SS.description: The origin, development and spread of the Spanish language and culture   throughout the world from pre-Roman times to current issues facing the   Spanish-speaking population in the United States.

SPAN 211A.title: Survey of Spanish-American Literature for Portuguese Graduate Students
SPAN 211A.description: Students will write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to enrich their preparation and ready them for their Ph.D.    examinations.  Colonial Spanish-American literature.

SPAN 211B.title: Survey of Spanish-American Literature for Portuguese Graduate Students
SPAN 211B.description: Students will write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to enrich their preparation and ready them for their Ph.D.    examinations. Nineteenth-century Spanish-American literature.

SPAN 211C.title: Survey of Spanish-American Literature for Portuguese Graduate Students
SPAN 211C.description: Students will write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to enrich their preparation and ready them for their Ph.D.    examinations. Twentieth-century literature.

SPAN 212.title: Research Methodologies and Theories of Literatures
SPAN 212.description: Approaches and methods for research in Hispanic and Portuguese and   Brazilian literatures. Techniques of literary scholarship will also be considered as well as the analysis and application of methods of current literaty theories and criticism.

SPAN 212A.title: Research Methods in Literature
SPAN 212A.description: Approaches and methods for research in Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian   literature. Study of main bibliographic resource with particular emphasis  on computer-aided research and resulting in the production of a    substantive on a field of graduate research.

SPAN 212B.title: Research Methods in Linguistics
SPAN 212B.description: Approaches and methods for research in Hispanic and Luso-Brazilian   linguistics. Study of main bibliographic resource with particular emphasis on computer-aided research and resulting in the production of a    substantive on a field of graduate research.

SPAN 213.title: Emotions and Affects in Spanish Culture
SPAN 213.description: Interrogates the emergence of affect as a critical perspective through which to understand culture. Taking Affect Theory as a starting point, we analyze different ways in which emotion and affects are socially produced in particular cultural contexts.

SPAN 214B.title: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach
SPAN 214B.description: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the Spanish system, as follows: morphology and syntax.

SPAN 214C.title: The Spanish Language: A Linguistic Approach
SPAN 214C.description: Study of the systematic aspects of language structure which make communication possible. Each quarter deals with a different aspect of the Spanish system, as follows: semantics.

SPAN 215.title: Women Authors of the Spanish Language
SPAN 215.description: An examination of women's strategies of self-figuration, traditions of   female expression, women's relationship to authorship and authority, and the relationship of Spanish-language writing to contemporary feminist  criticism.

SPAN 218.title: Individual Hispanic Authors and Special Topics
SPAN 218.comments: Course may be repeated for a total of 24 units (six courses, each a    different author).
SPAN 218.description: Intensive study of the work of an individual Hispanic author, to be chosen by the instructor.

SPAN 220A.title: Professional Training Colloquium
SPAN 220A.description: The course focuses on the skills needed to prepare for the job market  (CV's, cover letters, conference abstracts, course syllabi, mock     interviews). Guest speakers will also provide the opportunity to learn new methodologies, issues, and how to deliver papers effectively.

SPAN 220B.title: Professional Training Colloquium
SPAN 220B.description: The course focuses on the skills needed to prepare for the job market  (CV's, cover letters, conference abstracts, course syllabi, mock     interviews). Guest speakers will also provide the opportunity to learn new methodologies, issues, and how to deliver papers effectively.

SPAN 220C.title: Professional Training Colloquium
SPAN 220C.description: Course focuses on the skills needed to prepare for the job market (CV's, cover letters, conference abstracts, course syllabi, mock interviews).   Guest speakers will also provide the opportunity to learn new      methodologies, issues, and how to deliver papers effectively.

SPAN 221.title: History of Spanish and Portuguese Languages
SPAN 221.description: Selected topics in historical phonology in light of recent scholarship.

SPAN 222A.title: Studies in Medieval Peninsular Literature
SPAN 222A.comments: May be repeated for credit with consent of the department graduate adviser.
SPAN 222A.description: Selected topic studied in the light of recent scholarship. Students will write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to   enrich their preparation and ready them for their M.A. and Ph.D.     examinations.

SPAN 222B.title: Studies in Medieval Peninsular Literature
SPAN 222B.comments: May be repeated for credit with consent of the department graduate adviser.
SPAN 222B.description: Selected topic studied in the light of recent scholarship. Students will write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to   enrich their preparation and ready them for their M.A. and Ph.D.     examinations.

SPAN 240A.title: Studies on Cervantes
SPAN 240A.comments: May be repeated for credit with the consent of the department graduate   adviser.
SPAN 240A.description: Selected topics studied in the light of recent scholarship. Students will  write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to   enrich their preparation and ready them for their M.A. and Ph.D.     examinations.

SPAN 240B.title: Studies on Cervantes
SPAN 240B.comments: May be repeated for credit with the consent of the department graduate   adviser.
SPAN 240B.description: Selected topics studies in the light of recent scholarship. Students will  write an extensive paper and be responsible for additional readings to   enrich their preparation and ready them for their M.A. and Ph.D.     examinations.

SPAN 245.title: Studies in Spanish-American Colonial Literature
SPAN 245.comments: May be repeated for credit with the consent of the department graduate   adviser.
SPAN 245.description: Selected topics from the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries.

SPAN 285.title: Studies in Twentieth-Century Spanish-American Fiction
SPAN 285.comments: Course content may vary form quarter to quarter and may be repeated for  credit with the consent of the department graduate adviser.
SPAN 285.description: Seminar in selected authors of twentieth-century Spanish-American novel.

SPAN 287.title: Literature and Culture of the Postmodern Americas
SPAN 287.description: A study of hybridity and postmodernity in the narrative cultural productionof Latinos in the Americas, focusing on the eroding but not yet effaced  borders between various cultural and social spheres. Readings drawn from Latin American and U.S. Latino writers and theorists such as Garcia    Canclini, Cortazar, Piglia, Puig, Cisneros, Alvarez, Morales.

SPAN 291.title: TRANSLATION AND COGNITION
SPAN 291.description: EXPLORES THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COGNITIVE APPROACH TO TRANSLATION STUDIES AS IT APPLIES TO THEORY, RESEARCH METHODOLOGY, AND EXPERIMENTAL DESIGNS.

SPAN 293A.title: Capstone Seminar - Language and Translation Studies
SPAN 293A.description: The Capstone Seminar offers the graduate students from the Spanish and Portuguese Department the opportunity to conduct research alongside upstanding seniors who seek to obtain distinction in the Spanish major. The course offers M.A. and PhD. students the opportunity to hone their critical thinking, oral and writing skills. It also allows the graduate students the chance to mentor their undergraduate classmates by teaching them to analyze and contextualize primary and secondary sources within Language and Translation Studies.
